title: Extinction Rebellion launch action plan to blockade London for two weeks
text:
Performances, singing and speeches marked the launch event of the October Rebellion

(Picture: Getty)

Hundreds of Extinction Rebellion protesters have gathered in London ahead of their two-week blockade of London starting Monday.

Organisers expect the climate protest to be five times bigger than the April demonstration which blocked streets for up to a week, leading to 1,100 arrests.

They are spending almost £1 million on the elaborate ‘October Rebellion’, which will see protesters attempt to block central London roads for two weeks.

Groups from around the country will be deployed in locations around Westminster and support each other in trying to keep the area at a standstill.

They plan to replace activists who are arrested with fresh boots on the ground.

Extinction Rebellion activists in red robes were also seen at the April protests this year (Picture: AFP)

The monarch could be blocked from her Queen’s Speech on October 14, and activists have admitted their action could impact St Thomas’ hospital, which sits across the Thames from the Houses of Parliament.

Asked on Sky News whether they were concerned about disruption at the hospital, activist Savannah Lovelock replied they were ‘really sorry… but we are running out of time’.

They said they will stand aside for ambulances responding to emergencies.

Boris Johnson warns French PM Brexit cannot be delayed

Sunday’s opening ceremony featured performances, singing and meditation to ‘inspire’ demonstrators ahead of the protests.

Thousands of supporters have signed up for the march through the organising body and said they are willing risk arrest.

Others, including children and elderly people, are expected to participate in other ways. Numerous talks and performances will be held alongside the blockading actions.

Extinction Rebellion have issued a map showing 22 sites to be occupied, including 11 roads into Westminster and numerous government departments.

Police arrest a climate change activist blockading Waterloo bridge during April’s Extinction Rebellion protest (Picture: AFP)

The group has been stockpiling equipment including stages and sound systems at secret locations in central London before the protest.

They have spent £300,000 on equipment, lavatories, food for up to 30,000 protesters and expenses for organisers, as well as £200,000 on ‘arts and actions’.

Another £150,000 will be spent on transporting groups to the protests and £75,000 on training to help protesters know their rights if arrested.

Extinction Rebellion spokesperson Zoe Jones, 24, said: ‘The public perception of XR is that we’re disrupting ordinary people’s lives by blocking roads and that’s why this time we’re taking our protests to the seat of power and taking it to Westminster.’

‘We are on the public’s side and we are ordinary people who are extremely concerned.’

The group has told its activists not to cooperate with police so that they use up cells and officers’ time which could be spent arresting other protesters.

A boat is placed in the centre of Oxford Circus during during April’s demonstration (Picture: GETTY IMAGES)

They wrote on their website: ‘Police could often only arrest 100-200 people a day because the cells were full. If we fill them every day – the streets will remain ours.

‘That it is why we refuse bail, to fill up the cells and to show our open defiance of the system that is killing us.’

Ms Jones added: ‘There is a misconception with Extinction Rebellion that to be involved you have to be arrested but that is not the case.’

Policing the protests in April cost £16 million.

Actions have now begun in Guwahati, India, and Wellington New Zealand, where it is already October 7.

description: The climate activists hope their elaborate plan will shut down Westminster for two weeks.
